item.title: PHP Help
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:13, topic:519315”][quote author=justaguy link=topic=637779.msg4299433#msg4299433 date=1368739369]

[quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=637779.msg4299394#msg4299394 date=1368735511]

[quote author=justaguy link=topic=637779.msg4299391#msg4299391 date=1368734823]

They will be removed from php in the near future

They have been saying that since 5.3/5.4, there is still no official confirmation. Anthony Ferrara has made some points that the MySQL extension most likely won’t be removed entirely till after PHP 6 (which is a few years away). Too many sites/projects/frameworks use it to use the normal deprecation process. Even WordPress is still using it.

The MySQL extension isn’t even inherently insecure. It’s the bad usage that makes it that way.

I know they’ve been saying it for a while now but if people were to start using a different system now it’d make the change a lot easier. Not to mention the use of prepared statements is better than just escaping a string. The bad usage statement is the same for everything in php, or so I believe. PHP gets a bad name because people don’t use it to its full potential, a lot of PHP programmers have the “love it” attitude and their code is sloppy and that’s when they start to leave exploits. Then it comes back as a negative energy towards the language and the people who use it. Or that’s my views anyway.
[/quote]None of the examples even mention prepared statements, and you’re only going to find people suggesting that in the comments.

php.net:

Use prepared statements with bound variables. They are provided by PDO, by MySQLi and by other libraries.

???
[/quote]Are they in any of the code examples on that page (which users are more likely to copy/paste)?

They link to pages with code examples… Didn’t you read it?
[/quote]Yes but in a large page with many code examples, 2 small links near the bottom in a list are pretty insignificant. You’d have to know what you’re looking for or read the entire thing before you come to the conclusion that you should be using them, which most people probably won’t do. I was just poking fun, anyway. Don’t take it too seriously.[/quote]

LOL this is the internet. Of course I’m not (or hope I’m not) being overly dramatic about it…

item.title: PHP Help
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“Ruby, post:4, topic:519315”]Why are people still using mysql_ functions yet? I really can’t understand it for the life of me. They will be removed from php in the near future, there’s much better alternatives with plenty of tutorials kicking around but people still resort to the worst possible option. Read up on mysqli or PDO from either of those links, but you really need to stop using mysql_.

Also, for limiting the amount of characters:
[php]

<?php /** * If the string is longer than 50, strip it to 50 characters. */ if (strlen($some_long_str > 50) { $some_stripped_str = substr($some_long_str, 1, 50); } else { /** * If the string is less than 50 characters, switch it to the stripped string. */ $some_stripped_str = $some_long_str; } /** * Echo the new string. */ echo $some_stripped_str; [/php][/quote]People use it because that's what most code samples from this website use and it's on most PHP/MySQL tutorials online. This could all be easily solved by not using PHP and using a language that doesn't dump all the modules into the global namespace however.
